comments:
I will attach a screen shot of the key binding dialog for CTRL+M which shows 
that it is unmapped to "Maximize Active View or Editor" and at that it is 
unassigned. Clicking on Add, Remove or Restore in the dialog has no effect. 
Pressing CTRL+M in the java editor seems to have the same effect as pressing 
enter.

I200309300800

Created an attachment (id=6335)
Ctrl+M dialog

cannot press Add, Remove or Restore on this dialog

Ctrl+M can be unassigned. When key sequences are unassigned, the key events are allowed to pass 
through to the widget below. Ctrl+M is ASCII 13, or carriage return. The text editor takes this quite 
literally, and considers Ctrl+M a regular carriage return.

Changing the summary of this pr. May close it altogether. Comments?

why have you lowered the severity of this bug?
It is not possible to assign Ctrl+M (In General) to be "Maximize Active View or 
Editor" (which is what it is supposed to be by default!)
doug, please have a look at this.

wrong.  Could you please test on the most recent integration build?  Thank you.

should I open a seperate bug report with this stack trace?

Here are the steps I'm doing:
1.) Open Preferences.
2.) Select "Window" and "Maximize Active View or Editor".
3.) Select "Ctrl+M" from the "Assignments" table.
4.) Click "Remove"
5.) Click "Add"

The add actually works, but has an unfortunate visual bug of saying it is
"Ctrl+M (was: Maximize Active View or Editor)".  This is a known problem, which
I think we decide not to fix (a user-defined preference will persist even if the
default settings change, which is what this it trying to say).

Pressing "Restore" returns it to the initial state.

What are your steps?

following your steps when I got to step 4 
clicking Remove had no visual effect and neither did step 5 (clicking add). 
I tried clicking apply after step 5 and closing the preferences dialog.
After that Ctrl+M acts as though I have pressed Enter in my java editor.

I was expecting after step 5 for the key binding dialog to change the "-" to 
a "+" next to where it says "Ctrl+M (was: Maximize Active View or Editor)". 
That doesn't happen.

There is one last step.  Does this happen with a fresh workspace?  In other 
words, if you move your workspace somewhere else, and then start Eclipse, can 
you reproduce the problem?

with a fresh workspace the problem does not occur!. There are visual cues that 
something happens when you press the add remove or modify. Perhps my workspace 
is corrupt. any suggestions how I can fix my workspace without starting from 
scratch?

If you're not particularly attached to your key bindings, then try this:
1.) Find you workbench preferences file.  For me, this might be something 
like: ".workbench\.metadata\.plugins\org.eclipse.ui.workbench\pref_store.ini".
2.) Remove the line starting with "org.eclipse.ui.commands".  This line might 
look something like:

org.eclipse.ui.commands=<?xml version\="1.0" encoding\="UTF-8"?
>\n<org.eclipse.u
i.commands>\n<activeKeyConfiguration/>\n<keyBinding 
commandId\="org.eclipse.ui.w
indow.maximizePart" keySequence\="CTRL+M"/>\n</org.eclipse.ui.commands>\n


And, as a favour to us, could you attach the entire "pref_store.ini", so that 
we can continue to try to reproduce the bug.  Thanks.

Thank you, Nikolay.  I think your preferences file has narrowed down exactly 
what has happening -- even if its not clear how it got to be corrupted like 
that.

Chris -
I believe the problem is tied to the following entry is key preferences:
    <keyBinding keySequence\="CTRL+M" locale\="" platform\=""/>

Any ideas how this would have found its way into his preferences file?


(upgrading to normal, as this requires the user to manually edit their

in Comment #10.  A bug with two NPEs ... oh, boy....  ;)
